entity: Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region
entity_raw_name: 8.	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region
source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.2_CLUSTER I_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the Mission derives from Security Council resolution 2098 (2013) and various subsequent Council resolutions, the latest being resolution 2773 (2025). Established in 2013, the Mission is responsible for supporting the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework for the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Region, which was signed on 24 February 2013 by Angola, Burundi, the Central African Republic, the Congo, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Rwanda, South Africa, South Sudan, Uganda, the United Republic of Tanzania and Zambia, as well as representatives of the United Nations, the African Union, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR) and the Southern African Development Community, acting as guarantor institutions. On 31 January 2014, Kenya and the Sudan also signed the Framework. The Framework outlines national, regional and international commitments required to end the recurring cycles of violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and address the root causes of conflict in the region.

In relevant resolutions the Council emphasized the importance of commitments undertaken by the region under the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework and reiterated its support for the regional efforts underway with regard to the East African Community-led Nairobi process and the African Union-mandated Luanda process. In resolutions 2765 (2024) and 2773 (2025), the Council called on the Special Envoy to intensify his engagement to support the full implementation of the Framework as well as to support regional peace processes and strengthen regional diplomatic mediation efforts.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this Mission contributes, is to advance the effective implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework by supporting and facilitating political, security and economic engagements between the signatory countries, while ensuring coherent and coordinated support from regional and international organizations and other partners, in line with the United Nations Strategy for Peace Consolidation, Conflict Prevention and Conflict Resolution in the Great Lakes Region and its action plan.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:
Support signatory countries in efforts to implement the revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework;
Provide the Secretary-General’s good offices and enhance support to regional peace processes, including through assistance to mediation efforts and the implementation of respective agreements;
Support the implementation of regional non-military approaches against armed groups; and help strengthen existing security cooperation mechanisms;
Support the effective participation of civil society, women and youth in political and peacebuilding processes; promote the economic empowerment of youth;
Promote regional economic integration, including the implementation of the recommendations of the high-level regional workshop on natural resources held in 2021 in Khartoum;
Promote regional judicial cooperation and monitoring of human rights, including by supporting the implementation of the 2019 Nairobi and the 2022 Kinshasa Declarations.

Support the implementation of the United Nations regional strategy and its 2025-2027 Plan of Action, through effective coordination and provision of secretariat support to the Senior Policy Group and Implementation Support Mechanism.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
Signatory countries of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework implement recommendations from the revitalization process towards addressing conflict root causes;

Signatory countries engage faithfully in regional peace processes and implement political agreements reached contributing to de-escalation of bilateral tensions and improving the security and humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo;

Concerned countries enhance cooperation to address the threat posed by armed groups and coordinate regional disarmament, repatriation, and reintegration initiatives through the Contact and Coordination Group on non-military measures and its Operational Cell;
An increased number of civil society organizations, including women and youth contribute to regional peace processes and cross border peacebuilding initiatives;

Signatory countries strengthen regional judicial cooperation through the Great Lakes Judicial Cooperation Network, leading to an increased number of joint investigations, legal assistance and extradition requests, as well as prosecutions of cross-border crime;
Signatory countries increase economic cooperation and implement initiatives to curb the illicit exploitation of and trade in natural resources, with a focus on artisanal gold and coltan;
United Nations entities enhance coordination and ensure greater alignment between national strategic cooperation frameworks and the regional strategy’s objectives.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

Despite some progress as a result of diplomatic efforts, relations between some countries in the region will remain tense. The situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo will continue to face persisting insecurity and proliferation of armed groups;

Regional and international diplomatic efforts will lead to the signing in 2025 of an agreement to end the current crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, which will require implementation support;
Regional political processes will continue, requiring sustained support from the United Nations, regional and international partners to ensure the full implementation of agreements reached;
Continued support will be required for the participation and contribution of women and youth in peace processes and community peacebuilding;
Signatory countries of the revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework will demonstrate renewed political will to implement commitments made under the Framework;
International Partners will continue to support efforts towards a political settlement of the conflict in the Great Lakes region.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Mission will enhance coordination with the ICGLR to support complementary approaches under the revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework and the Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region. To further align approaches with international partners, the Special Envoy will continue to participate in the International Contact Group.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mission will continue to closely work with MONUSCO. Support to regional peace efforts will be coordinated through a dedicated mechanism, involving MONUSCO, UNOCA, and UNOAU. The Senior Policy Group, chaired by the Special Envoy, along with its Implementation Support Mechanism and the Integrated Secretariat, will continue to ensure alignment among United Nations entities in the region, leveraging expertise and information sharing across offices, thereby enhancing resource efficiencies, while maintaining the distinct mandates of each entity.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. In addition to high-level advocacy initiatives, the Mission supports the Advisory Board for Women, Peace and Security (WPS) in the Great Lakes Region in its efforts to promote women’s participation in peacebuilding, political and electoral processes and to strengthen the monitoring and evaluation capacities of the mechanisms on sexual and gender-based violence of the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR).
Programme performance in 2024
Advancement of the women and peace and security (WPS) agenda for the effective revitalization of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework

In 2024, the mission advanced the WPS agenda and advocated for women’s inclusion in regional political processes. The mission, together with ICGLR and partners, launched the regional Gender Barometer, a tool to enhance data and analysis on WPS and advance gender equality across ICGLR Member States. The first Gender Barometer report was validated in October 2024 and endorsed by the Ministers in charge of Gender in ICGLR Member States in November.

To amplify the voices of women in regional peace efforts, the mission organized a regional women’s forum in cooperation with the Government of Burundi, as chair of the Regional Oversight Mechanism. The forum recommended the appointment of a goodwill ambassador to champion the aspirations of women in the region. An additional regional forum was organized in Luanda under the leadership of President João Lourenço. The forum proposed the mobilization of existing mechanisms comprising women leaders to support the mediation efforts under the Luanda Process and the establishment of a trust fund for women working on peace and security. The mission also enhanced partnerships with the AU and ICGLR to promote women’s inclusion in dialogue and peace processes.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 35).
Table 35 – Performance measure

table_content.text: High-level advocacy by the Special Envoy on the need for a stronger participation of women in peace and political processes

The Special Envoy and the AU facilitated a women-led mission to the DRC to promote women's participation in regional political processes and assess the deteriorating security and humanitarian conditions in IDP camps
Increased awareness of WPS progress and challenges in the region through the development of the regional Gender Barometer and validation of its first report

children.text: Planned result for 2026
A revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework better addresses the root causes of recurrent crises in the Great Lakes region – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission provided technical support to the development of a draft action plan for the revitalisation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework, aiming at ensuring enhanced implementation of the commitments made by the signatory countries. The Special Envoy undertook good offices efforts to address the ongoing security and humanitarian crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and to promote a de-escalation of bilateral tensions. The mission provided technical support to the Nairobi and Luanda processes and promoted a convergence of views among the signatory countries on issues driving conflict dynamics. The mission also supported efforts to identify foreign ex-combatants willing to repatriate and facilitated the adoption of a draft common criminal policy on cross-border crime.

However,  due to the deteriorating security and humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and increased tensions between the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Rwanda, some engagements were postponed, notably a project on economic cooperation, land and conflict, missions of the Contact and Coordination Group as well as a meeting of the Advisory Board for WPS.

In 2026, the mission will continue to support the implementation of the recommendations developed for the revitalisation of the Framework to ensure enhanced coordination and complementarity among regional peace initiatives as well as a more concerted international support thereto. This includes the disarmament, repatriation and reintegration of foreign armed combatants operating in eastern DRC, the transparent management of natural resources and renewed cooperation on criminal conflict-related cross-border cases, among others. The office will integrate WPS and gender perspectives to enhance capacities and opportunities for women to participate in conflict prevention and regional peace processes, and promote social cohesion in the Great Lakes.
Lessons learned and planned change

The escalating crisis in the region has highlighted the need for closely aligned efforts at regional and international levels to support dialogue and confidence-building as well as the continued political will of the concerned  parties to commit to a political settlement of the conflict; and enhanced support to efforts to address the root causes of recurrent conflict in the region. In response, the Special Envoy will further step up the Secretary-General’s good offices efforts, supported by enhanced technical support from the Mission to the ongoing regional peace processes, including to the implementation of agreements reached. As part of the revitalization of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework, the Mission’s support will focus on priority areas of addressing conflict root causes.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 36).
Table 36 – Performance measure:

table_content.text:
Enhanced consultations, coordination and joint action among the guarantor institutions in support of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework
Initiatives taken by regional and subregional organizations and signatory countries of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework to support peaceful, inclusive and credible political and electoral processes

Initiatives under the second and third phases of the action plan of the United Nations Strategy for Peace Consolidation, Conflict Prevention and Conflict Resolution in the Great Lakes Region were implemented, including flagship initiative 2, providing an assessment of the impact and future path of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework

Initiatives under the second and third phases of the action plan of the United Nations Strategy for Peace Consolidation, Conflict Prevention and Conflict Resolution in the Great Lakes Region were implemented, including flagship initiative 2, providing an assessment of the impact and future path of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework and flagship 3 on strengthening the role of civil society organizations, women and youth in political processes and peacebuilding structures

Implementation of the road map for the revitalization of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework.
A revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework effectively supports well-coordinated regional political and diplomatic engagement towards a durable political settlement of tensions and instability in the Great Lakes region

Continued implementation of the Action Plan for the revitalization of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework
A revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework effectively supports well-coordinated and inclusive regional approaches and measures to address the root causes of conflict, 
Sustained engagement of the DRC and neighbouring countries in political dialogue results in the implementation of a regional peace agreement, supported by the United Nations
Regional confidence-building measures are progressively implemented, incrementally reestablishing trust and leading to a reduction of violent conflict

children.text: Deliverables
Table 37 lists all deliverables of the mission.
Table 37 – Deliverables for the period 2024–2026 by category and subcategory

table_content.text: A.	Facilitation of the intergovernmental process and expert bodies
1.	Reports of the Secretary-General to the Security Council
Substantive services for meetings (number of three-hour meetings)
2.	Meetings of the Security Council, and the Peacebuilding Commission
B.	Generation and transfer of knowledge
Field and technical cooperation projects (number of projects)
3.	Projects on economic cooperation, land and conflict
4.	Projects to promote cross-border trade and investment
Seminars, workshops and training events (number of days)
5.	Workshop on exchange of lessons learned from elections and political processes
6.	Workshop on economic cooperation, natural resources and conflict
7.	Workshops on resolving existing challenges in the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework
8.	Workshop on youth engagement on peace and security
9.	Advisory Board for Women, Peace and Security in the Great Lakes Region meetings
10.  Annual meeting of the Great Lakes Judicial Cooperation Network in support of regional judicial cooperation
Fact-finding, monitoring and investigation missions (number of missions)
11 .	      Missions of the operational cell of the Contact and Coordination Group on non-military measures

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 38 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 39 – Human resources
a	Comprising one Other level.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $5,623,800 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($4,884,200) for the continuation of 30 posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 1 D-1, 5 P-5, 7 P-4, 5 P-3, 1 Field Service, 1 National Professional Officer, 1 General Service (Other level)) and 7 Local level, as well as operational costs ($739,600), comprising costs for consultants and consulting services ($22,000), official travel ($296,000), facilities and infrastructure ($23,500), ground transportation ($19,600), air operations ($15,600), communications and information technology ($122,300), medical ($12,900) and other supplies, services and equipment ($227,700).
For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.

Vacancy rates of 12.7 per cent and 12.5 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international and General Service and Local level staff, respectively, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the estimates for the National Professional Officer on the basis of the expected recruitment timeline for the post.

The increased in the requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to increased requirements for civilian personnel, resulting from the application of a lower vacancy rate of 12.7 per cent compared with the rate of 19.3 per cent applied in 2025 for international staff, and the application of the latest salary rates. The increase is offset in part by: (a) the non-recurring acquisition of furniture and IT equipment; (b) reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical  flight hour utilization rates; (c) reduced requirements for individual contractors; and (d) lower requirements for other services with respect to financial administrative services under other supplies, services and equipment class.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,800,000 are estimated to support the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework through various projects under different thematic areas.
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,500,000 are estimated to support the implementation of the project for the reduction of small arms circulation in the Great Lakes region.
The decrease in the estimated extrabudgetary resources to be utilized in 2026 as compared with 2025 is due to lower projected contributions pending renewed agreements with partners.
